<ce:simple-para id="sp0085" view="all">Survival (%) of <ce:italic>G. mellonella</ce:italic> larvae 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h after being infected with a lethal dose of <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> fungal cells). For prophylactic treatment, the test compound was administered 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h prior to infection with <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> cells, while for the treatment of infection experiments the compound was administered 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h after infection with the fungal cells. Compounds were administered at a concentration of 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μg<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>). Data for the control, silver nitrate and ketoconazole have previously been published <ce:cross-ref id="c0300" refid="b0030">[6]</ce:cross-ref>.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st100">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Silver(I) complexes of substituted imidazoles have been synthesised and screened for their <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic> antimicrobial activity. The complexes offer promise as potential therapeutics.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st130">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (9-acaH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9-anthracenecarboxylic acid) interacts with DMSO and a selection of substituted imidazoles giving [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(DMSO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Silver(I) complexes of substituted imidazoles have been synthesised and screened for their in vitro and in vivo antimicrobial activity. The complexes offer promise as potential therapeutics.

Abstract

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (9-acaH=9-anthracenecarboxylic acid) interacts with DMSO and a selection of substituted imidazoles giving [Ag4(DMSO)4(9-aca)4] n  (1), [Ag(2-Me-imH)2(9-aca)] (2), [Ag(4-Ph-imH)2(9-aca)] (3), [Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)2(9-aca)] (4), [Ag(2-Mebenz-im)] (6), [Ag(Benz-im)] (7), [Ag(2-Ph-im)] (8) and [Ag(4,5-CN-im)] (9) (2-Me-imH=2-methylimidazole; 4-Ph-imH=4-phenylimidazole; 2-Mebenz-imH=2-methylbenzimidazole; Benz-imH=benzimidazole; 2-Ph-imH=2-phenylbenzimidazole; 4,5-CN-imH=4,5-dicyanoimidazole). In the carboxylate/imidazole complexes 2-4, the imidazole ligand is in the neutral form, whilst in complexes 6-9 the imidazolate ligand is deprotonated and no carboxylate ligand is present. Attempted recrystallization of 4 from EtOH gives the metal-free, imidazolium salt, 2-Mebenz-imH2)(9-aca)⋅H2O (5). The X-ray crystal structures of complexes 1 and 2 and the salt 5 were determined. Antimicrobial screening showed that the Ag(I) complexes were substantially more active against the fungus Candida albicans than the bacterial species, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Escherichia coli. Some of the complexes offer a good prognosis for Galleria mellonella (larvae of the greater wax moth) infected with a lethal dose of C. albicans cells.

<ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0190" view="all">Recent World Health Organization (WHO) publications  have highlighted the critical situation of antimicrobial drug resistance and that too few new compounds are being developed to combat infectious agents. In a recent publication, Lansdown chronicles the uses of silver-containing therapeutics in the treatment of bacterial, fungal and viral infections . Besides its high bactericidal and fungicidal attributes, and in stark contrast to most other medicinally-active transition metal ions, Ag(I) ions are relatively well tolerated by mammalian cells .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recent World Health Organization (WHO) publications  have highlighted the critical situation of antimicrobial drug resistance and that too few new compounds are being developed to combat infectious agents. In a recent publication, Lansdown chronicles the uses of silver-containing therapeutics in the treatment of bacterial, fungal and viral infections . Besides its high bactericidal and fungicidal attributes, and in stark contrast to most other medicinally-active transition metal ions, Ag(I) ions are relatively well tolerated by mammalian cells .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">It has been reported that coordinating imidazole and derivatised imidazoles to a Ag(I) centre generally enhances the antimicrobial effects of the metal ion. For example, Kleyi et al.  studied the antimicrobial activity of a family of 2-hydroxymethyl-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-alkylimidazole ligands and their Ag(I) complexes and found that whereas the metal-free ligands were poorly active against <ce:italic>Escherichia coli</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>Candida albicans,</ce:italic> imidazoles with long pendant alkyl chains displayed high activity against <ce:italic>Staphylococcus aureus</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>Bacillus spizizenii</ce:italic>. Ag(I) complexes containing imidazole ligands with shorter alkyl chains were more active against <ce:italic>E. coli</ce:italic>, whilst those with longer chains displayed higher activity against <ce:italic>B. spizizenii</ce:italic>. The authors attributed the antimicrobial effect on <ce:italic>E. coli</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> solely to the Ag(I) ions since the metal-free ligands displayed poor activity against these organisms. They also concluded that the activity of the complexes containing ligands with longer alkyl chain lengths was due to a combination of the Ag(I) ion and the active imidazole.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It has been reported that coordinating imidazole and derivatised imidazoles to a Ag(I) centre generally enhances the antimicrobial effects of the metal ion. For example, Kleyi et al.  studied the antimicrobial activity of a family of 2-hydroxymethyl-N-alkylimidazole ligands and their Ag(I) complexes and found that whereas the metal-free ligands were poorly active against Escherichia coli and Candida albicans, imidazoles with long pendant alkyl chains displayed high activity against Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus spizizenii. Ag(I) complexes containing imidazole ligands with shorter alkyl chains were more active against E. coli, whilst those with longer chains displayed higher activity against B. spizizenii. The authors attributed the antimicrobial effect on E. coli and C. albicans solely to the Ag(I) ions since the metal-free ligands displayed poor activity against these organisms. They also concluded that the activity of the complexes containing ligands with longer alkyl chain lengths was due to a combination of the Ag(I) ion and the active imidazole.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">We have previously synthesised and screened mononuclear, multinuclear and polymeric Ag(I) complexes comprising imidazole and N1-substituted imidazoles, and found that [Ag(imH)<ce:inf loc="post">2.3</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">0.7</ce:inf>](9-aca), [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(imH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], {[Ag(1-Me-im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]}, {[Ag(1-Bu-im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]} and [Ag(apim)](9-aca)·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (imH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>imidazole; 1-Me-im<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1-methylimidazole; 1-Bu-im<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1-butylimidazole; apim<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1-(3-aminoproply)imidazole; 9-acaH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9-anthracenecarboxylic acid) were all highly active, <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic>, against <ce:italic>E. coli</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>S. aureus</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> cells . Moreover, <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic> studies conducted on larvae of the greater wax moth (<ce:italic>Galleria mellonella</ce:italic>) infected with a lethal dose of <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> cells revealed that pre- and post-administration of some of these Ag(I) complexes increased the chances of survival of the juveniles. Encouraged by these results, [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] has now been used as the starting material for the preparation of a new series of Ag(I) complexes containing relatively cheap, commercially available imidazole ligands carrying substituents at positions other than the pyrrole-type N1 atom of the ring (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). In addition to their structural and physical properties, the <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic> antimicrobial activities of the complexes are also reported.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We have previously synthesised and screened mononuclear, multinuclear and polymeric Ag(I) complexes comprising imidazole and N1-substituted imidazoles, and found that [Ag(imH)2.3(CH3CN)0.7](9-aca), [Ag6(imH)4(9-aca)6(MeOH)2], {[Ag(1-Me-im)2]2[Ag4(9-aca)6]}, {[Ag(1-Bu-im)2]2[Ag4(9-aca)6]} and [Ag(apim)](9-aca)⋅H2O (imH=imidazole; 1-Me-im=1-methylimidazole; 1-Bu-im=1-butylimidazole; apim=1-(3-aminoproply)imidazole; 9-acaH=9-anthracenecarboxylic acid) were all highly active, in vitro, against E. coli, S. aureus and C. albicans cells . Moreover, in vivo studies conducted on larvae of the greater wax moth (Galleria mellonella) infected with a lethal dose of C. albicans cells revealed that pre- and post-administration of some of these Ag(I) complexes increased the chances of survival of the juveniles. Encouraged by these results, [Ag2(9-aca)2] has now been used as the starting material for the preparation of a new series of Ag(I) complexes containing relatively cheap, commercially available imidazole ligands carrying substituents at positions other than the pyrrole-type N1 atom of the ring ( ). In addition to their structural and physical properties, the in vitro and in vivo antimicrobial activities of the complexes are also reported.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st015">Reagents and instrumentation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. The syntheses of all silver complexes were conducted in the absence of light and the products were stored in the dark at all times. [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] was prepared from K<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>(9-aca)<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> and AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in accordance with the literature method . Infrared spectra (as KBr discs) were recorded in the region 4000–370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on a Perkin Elmer System 2000 FT spectrometer. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectra, recorded as solutions in deuterated dimethylsulfoxide ((CD<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO), were recorded on a Bruker Avance spectrometer operating at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz and a probe temperature of 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Microanalytical data were provided by the Microanalytical Laboratory, University College Dublin, Belfield, Dublin 4, Ireland.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Reagents and instrumentation

Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. The syntheses of all silver complexes were conducted in the absence of light and the products were stored in the dark at all times. [Ag2(9-aca)2] was prepared from K+(9-aca)- and AgNO3 in accordance with the literature method . Infrared spectra (as KBr discs) were recorded in the region 4000-370cm-1 on a Perkin Elmer System 2000 FT spectrometer. 1H NMR spectra, recorded as solutions in deuterated dimethylsulfoxide ((CD3)2SO), were recorded on a Bruker Avance spectrometer operating at 300MHz and a probe temperature of 25°C. Microanalytical data were provided by the Microanalytical Laboratory, University College Dublin, Belfield, Dublin 4, Ireland.

<ce:section-title id="st020">X-ray crystal structure determinations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">X-ray crystallographic data (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>) were collected at 150(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on a Bruker APEX II diffractometer using Mo <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using all the reflections . All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined using anisotropic atomic displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were inserted at calculated positions using a riding model except for those bonded to oxygen or nitrogen in compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>; these were located from difference maps and refined under geometric restraints. One of the two independent 9-aca groups in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was disordered, this was modelled as 60:40 occupancy of two overlapping sites.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystal structure determinations

X-ray crystallographic data ( ) were collected at 150(2)K on a Bruker APEX II diffractometer using Mo K α radiation (λ =0.71073Å) and semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 using all the reflections . All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined using anisotropic atomic displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were inserted at calculated positions using a riding model except for those bonded to oxygen or nitrogen in compound 3; these were located from difference maps and refined under geometric restraints. One of the two independent 9-aca groups in complex 1 was disordered, this was modelled as 60:40 occupancy of two overlapping sites.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st025">Biological screening</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">
<ce:italic>E. coli</ce:italic>, MRSA, <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>G. mellonella</ce:italic> (larvae of the greater wax moth) were sourced and stored as previously described . Routine protocols were used to determine the <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> antibacterial and antifungal properties of the complexes . <ce:italic>G. mellonella</ce:italic> were utilised to assess the <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic> toxicity of the complexes and to establish fungal pathogenicity . Two <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic> antifungal treatment protocols were used to determine fungal pathogenicity . For the <ce:italic>prophylactic treatment</ce:italic>, larvae were injected with a solution/suspension of the test complex and after 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h they were inoculated with a lethal dose of <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> cells. For the <ce:italic>treatment of infection</ce:italic>, larvae were first inoculated with a lethal dose of fungal cells and after 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h the test solution/suspension was administered. Larvae survival was monitored 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h following the treatment protocols.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Biological screening

 E. coli, MRSA, C. albicans and G. mellonella (larvae of the greater wax moth) were sourced and stored as previously described . Routine protocols were used to determine the in vitro antibacterial and antifungal properties of the complexes . G. mellonella were utilised to assess the in vivo toxicity of the complexes and to establish fungal pathogenicity . Two in vivo antifungal treatment protocols were used to determine fungal pathogenicity . For the prophylactic treatment, larvae were injected with a solution/suspension of the test complex and after 1h they were inoculated with a lethal dose of C. albicans cells. For the treatment of infection, larvae were first inoculated with a lethal dose of fungal cells and after 1h the test solution/suspension was administered. Larvae survival was monitored 72h following the treatment protocols.

Chemical synthesis

[Ag4(DMSO)4(9-aca)4] n  (1)

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (0.100g, 0.15mmoles) was dissolved in dimethylsulfoxide (4cm3) and the mixture heated to 80°C for 20min. Ethanol (15cm3) was added and the solution was brought to reflux and then filtered. The filtrate was left to stand and after 3days yellow, needle-like crystals were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol and allowed to air-dry (0.062g yield 50%). Soluble in MeCN and DMSO. Molecular weight 814.44gmol-1. Anal. Calc.: C, 50.14; H, 3.71. Found: C, 50.22; H, 3.70%. IR (cm-1): 3411, 3050, 1620, 1587, 1565, 1538, 1427, 1389, 1320, 1276, 1018. 1H NMR (δ, DMSO): 8.45 (s, 1H); 8.18 (m, 2H); 8.05 (m, 2H); 7.48 (m, 4H); 2.56 (s, 6H).

<ce:section-title id="st080">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st085">Synthesis and characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">In our previous work  involving the reaction of [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] with imidazole and imidazoles substituted at the 1-position (pyrrole-type nitrogen, N1), it was found that slight changes in either the reaction solvent or the structure of the imidazole ligand had a marked and somewhat unpredictable effect on the composition of the isolated complex. An overriding structural theme amongst the complexes [Ag(imidH)<ce:inf loc="post">2.3</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">0.7</ce:inf>](9-aca), [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(imidH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], {[Ag(1-Me-im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]} and {[Ag(1-Bu-im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]}, was the prevelance of bis(imidazole)silver(I) entities, in which two neutral imidazole ligands coordinate <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> their imine N-atoms in an almost linear N–Ag–N fashion. Similarly, [Ag(apim)](9-aca)·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  and [Ag(apim)]ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
 had the imine nitrogen of one apim and the nitrogen of the pendant amine function of a neighbouring apim coordinated to the metal centre, with the N–Ag–N bond angle within the polymeric framework being <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 177°. Additionally, the imidazole ligands in [Ag(imH)<ce:inf loc="post">2.3</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">0.7</ce:inf>](9-aca) and [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(imH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] coordinate as neutral molecules (pyrrole N1 not deprotonated). In the present work, where [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] has been reacted with a range of imidazoles bearing substituents at positions other than N1, it is again apparent that relatively minor variations in the structure of the incoming imidazole ligand, and in some cases the reaction solvent, can dramatically affect product formulation. Furthermore, some of the imidazoles are seen to deprotonate at the pyrrole N1 atom to give a heterocyclic, anionic ligand and thus eliminating the requirement for a 9-aca<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion.</ce:para>

Results and discussion

Synthesis and characterization

In our previous work  involving the reaction of [Ag2(9-aca)2] with imidazole and imidazoles substituted at the 1-position (pyrrole-type nitrogen, N1), it was found that slight changes in either the reaction solvent or the structure of the imidazole ligand had a marked and somewhat unpredictable effect on the composition of the isolated complex. An overriding structural theme amongst the complexes [Ag(imidH)2.3(CH3CN)0.7](9-aca), [Ag6(imidH)4(9-aca)6(MeOH)2], {[Ag(1-Me-im)2]2[Ag4(9-aca)6]} and {[Ag(1-Bu-im)2]2[Ag4(9-aca)6]}, was the prevelance of bis(imidazole)silver(I) entities, in which two neutral imidazole ligands coordinate via their imine N-atoms in an almost linear N-Ag-N fashion. Similarly, [Ag(apim)](9-aca)⋅H2O  and [Ag(apim)]ClO4  had the imine nitrogen of one apim and the nitrogen of the pendant amine function of a neighbouring apim coordinated to the metal centre, with the N-Ag-N bond angle within the polymeric framework being ca. 177°. Additionally, the imidazole ligands in [Ag(imH)2.3(CH3CN)0.7](9-aca) and [Ag6(imH)4(9-aca)6(MeOH)2] coordinate as neutral molecules (pyrrole N1 not deprotonated). In the present work, where [Ag2(9-aca)2] has been reacted with a range of imidazoles bearing substituents at positions other than N1, it is again apparent that relatively minor variations in the structure of the incoming imidazole ligand, and in some cases the reaction solvent, can dramatically affect product formulation. Furthermore, some of the imidazoles are seen to deprotonate at the pyrrole N1 atom to give a heterocyclic, anionic ligand and thus eliminating the requirement for a 9-aca- anion.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Synthetic routes to the new complexes are summarised in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>. [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(DMSO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was readily prepared in 50% yield by heating [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] in DMSO and ethanol (). The X-ray crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was determined () and selected bond lengths and angles are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>. Although the asymmetric unit is {Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMSO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}, the complex is probably better described as a polymer made up of centrosymmetric tetranuclear [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(DMSO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] units linked into chains by bridging two further DMSO ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The short Ag1–Ag2 and longer Ag1–Ag1′ bond lengths in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (2.9144(4) and 3.1468(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively) contrast with short and long metal–metal distances in the polymeric starting material, [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (2.8508(9) and 3.657(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively) . In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each carboxylate group forms a μ-1,3-bridge between Ag1 and Ag2, additionally O11 is a single atom bridge between Ag1 and Ag1′ while O31 and O32 bind to Ag1 in chelate fashion. The DMSO ligand containing O1 bridges Ag1 and Ag2′ within a tetranuclear subunit and the second DMSO, which contains O2, links these units into chains running parallel to the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis by bridging Ag2 and Ag2″ (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The average Ag–O bonds for the carboxylate and DMSO ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are similar (2.423 and 2.448<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively), but are both somewhat longer than the Ag–O(carboxylate) bonds in [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (average 2.293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the carboxylate bridging bidentate and O-bridging bonds). These longer metal–oxygen (carboxylate) bond lengths in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be a consequence of the increased number of donor atoms (increased electron density) surrounding the metal centres.</ce:para>

The X-ray crystal structure of 1 was determined () and selected bond lengths and angles are given in  . Although the asymmetric unit is {Ag2(9-aca)2(DMSO)2}, the complex is probably better described as a polymer made up of centrosymmetric tetranuclear [Ag4(9-aca)4(DMSO)2] units linked into chains by bridging two further DMSO ligands ( ). The short Ag1-Ag2 and longer Ag1-Ag1' bond lengths in 1 (2.9144(4) and 3.1468(5)Å, respectively) contrast with short and long metal-metal distances in the polymeric starting material, [Ag2(9-aca)2] (2.8508(9) and 3.657(1)Å, respectively) . In 1, each carboxylate group forms a μ-1,3-bridge between Ag1 and Ag2, additionally O11 is a single atom bridge between Ag1 and Ag1' while O31 and O32 bind to Ag1 in chelate fashion. The DMSO ligand containing O1 bridges Ag1 and Ag2' within a tetranuclear subunit and the second DMSO, which contains O2, links these units into chains running parallel to the a axis by bridging Ag2 and Ag2" ( ). The average Ag-O bonds for the carboxylate and DMSO ligands in 1 are similar (2.423 and 2.448Å, respectively), but are both somewhat longer than the Ag-O(carboxylate) bonds in [Ag2(9-aca)2] (average 2.293Å for the carboxylate bridging bidentate and O-bridging bonds). These longer metal-oxygen (carboxylate) bond lengths in 1 may be a consequence of the increased number of donor atoms (increased electron density) surrounding the metal centres.

A band is observed at 708<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the symmetric stretching vibration of the S<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O moiety along with a strong band at 955<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> corresponding to the S–CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> rocking vibration of the methyl groups . elements.clean_text: The IR spectrum of 1 is very similar to that of [Ag2(9-aca)2] apart from the inclusion of the bands associated with the DMSO ligands. A band is observed at 708cm-1 for the symmetric stretching vibration of the SO moiety along with a strong band at 955cm-1 corresponding to the S-CH3 rocking vibration of the methyl groups . Using this value it is not possible to identify the carboxylate coordination mode as predictions with Δ(OCO) values of ca. 165cm-1 have been shown to be untrustworthy .

<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), the only difference being the presence of a singlet at 2.56<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm for the methyl groups of the DMSO ligands. It is believed that the DMSO ligands dissociate in solution as the position of this singlet is unchanged when compared to uncoordinated DMSO. Coordination to the silver ion is expected to cause a shielding of the DMSO methyl protons but this is not evident from the spectrum.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0100" view="all">[Ag(2-Me-imH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) was synthesised from [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and 2-methylimidazole (2-Me-imH) in 51% yield using acetonitrile as the reaction solvent (). Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was recrystallised from acetonitrile and the X-ray crystal structure solved (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor> and ). In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the Ag(I) ion is coordinated to the imine nitrogen atoms of the two imidazole rings and also to one carboxylate oxygen atom of the anthracene ligand. This monodentate Ag–O bond length (2.4941(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) is significantly longer than the average Ag–O distance for the bridging bidentate and O-bridging bonds in [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (2.293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The average Ag–N bond length in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (2.113<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) is similar to that found for the ordered, transoid imidazoles in [Ag(imH)<ce:inf loc="post">2.3</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">0.7</ce:inf>](9-aca) (2.126<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and also to the Ag–N bonds in [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(imH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (2.088<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). As is the case in the latter two complexes, the imidazole ligands in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are coordinated approximately linearly to each other (N(31)–Ag(1)–N(21) bond angle of 162.07(9)°) with the 9-aca<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand almost perpendicular (N(31)–Ag(1)–O(1) bond angle of 96.93(8)°). The silver ion does not interact significantly with other donors or with neighbouring silver ions (closest Ag⋯Ag distance is 4.1930(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The methyl groups at the 2-position on the imidazole ring are in a <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-conformation to each other and lie approximately perpendicular to the plane of the anthracene ring ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: [Ag(2-Me-imH)2(9-aca)] (2) was synthesised from [Ag2(9-aca)2] and 2-methylimidazole (2-Me-imH) in 51% yield using acetonitrile as the reaction solvent (). Complex 2 was recrystallised from acetonitrile and the X-ray crystal structure solved (    and ). In 2, the Ag(I) ion is coordinated to the imine nitrogen atoms of the two imidazole rings and also to one carboxylate oxygen atom of the anthracene ligand. This monodentate Ag-O bond length (2.4941(19)Å) is significantly longer than the average Ag-O distance for the bridging bidentate and O-bridging bonds in [Ag2(9-aca)2] (2.293Å). The average Ag-N bond length in 2 (2.113Å) is similar to that found for the ordered, transoid imidazoles in [Ag(imH)2.3(CH3CN)0.7](9-aca) (2.126Å) and also to the Ag-N bonds in [Ag6(imH)4(9-aca)6(MeOH)2] (2.088Å). As is the case in the latter two complexes, the imidazole ligands in 2 are coordinated approximately linearly to each other (N(31)-Ag(1)-N(21) bond angle of 162.07(9)°) with the 9-aca- ligand almost perpendicular (N(31)-Ag(1)-O(1) bond angle of 96.93(8)°). The silver ion does not interact significantly with other donors or with neighbouring silver ions (closest Ag⋯Ag distance is 4.1930(5)Å). The methyl groups at the 2-position on the imidazole ring are in a cis-conformation to each other and lie approximately perpendicular to the plane of the anthracene ring ().

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Three sets of interactions define the packing of the molecules in the crystal lattice. The non-coordinated carboxylate oxygen atom (O2) is hydrogen bonded to the imidazole NH groups of two neighbouring molecules ( and ), this generates a three-dimensional hydrogen bonded network. There are also two sets of π–π interactions: First the imidazole groups on adjacent molecules are paired (under 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) so that the mean interplanar distance is 3.33<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the centroid–centroid distance is 3.52<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Neighbouring anthracene groups are also paired, with π–π overlap of their outer rims (C8–C12 and C10–C10, 3.354 and 3.363<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively under symmetry operation ½<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, ½<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>). Together, these interactions generate π–π-linked chains parallel to the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic> diagonals ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Three sets of interactions define the packing of the molecules in the crystal lattice. The non-coordinated carboxylate oxygen atom (O2) is hydrogen bonded to the imidazole NH groups of two neighbouring molecules ( and ), this generates a three-dimensional hydrogen bonded network. There are also two sets of π-π interactions: First the imidazole groups on adjacent molecules are paired (under 1- x, -y, 2- z) so that the mean interplanar distance is 3.33Å and the centroid-centroid distance is 3.52Å. Neighbouring anthracene groups are also paired, with π-π overlap of their outer rims (C8-C12 and C10-C10, 3.354 and 3.363Å, respectively under symmetry operation ½- x, ½- y, 2- z). Together, these interactions generate π-π-linked chains parallel to the ab diagonals ().

<ce:para id="p0120" view="all">[Ag(4-Ph-imH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) was synthesised from [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and 4-phenylimidazole (4-Ph-imH) in good yield (81%) (). The IR spectrum of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> contains bands associated with the imidazole and anthracene carboxylate ligands, with the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">(OCO)asym</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">(OCO)sym</ce:inf> vibrations occurring at 1553 and 1424<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively (Δ<ce:inf loc="post">(OCO)</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>129<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). In the <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectrum of (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) the signals for the anthracene protons appear in similar positions to those in [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Peaks for the 4-Ph-imH protons appear at 7.88, 7.83, 7.59, 7.39 and 7.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm and these are shifted downfield in comparison to those observed in the spectrum of the free ligand. Furthermore, peak integrals indicate that the ratio of 9-aca:4-Ph-imH is 1:2. Thus, these combined IR, NMR and microanalytical data suggest that <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> may be structurally similar to [Ag(2-Me-imH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: [Ag(4-Ph-imH)2(9-aca)] (3) was synthesised from [Ag2(9-aca)2] and 4-phenylimidazole (4-Ph-imH) in good yield (81%) (). The IR spectrum of 3 contains bands associated with the imidazole and anthracene carboxylate ligands, with the ν (OCO)asym and ν (OCO)sym vibrations occurring at 1553 and 1424cm-1, respectively (Δ(OCO) =129cm-1). In the 1H NMR spectrum of (3) the signals for the anthracene protons appear in similar positions to those in [Ag2(9-aca)2] and complexes 1 and 2. Peaks for the 4-Ph-imH protons appear at 7.88, 7.83, 7.59, 7.39 and 7.25ppm and these are shifted downfield in comparison to those observed in the spectrum of the free ligand. Furthermore, peak integrals indicate that the ratio of 9-aca:4-Ph-imH is 1:2. Thus, these combined IR, NMR and microanalytical data suggest that 3 may be structurally similar to [Ag(2-Me-imH)2(9-aca)] (2).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0125" view="all">Spectral and microanalytical data for [Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), which was synthesised in high yield from [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and 2-methylbenzimidazole (2-Mebenz-imH) in acetonitrile, suggests that this complex is isostructural with <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Spectral and microanalytical data for [Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)2(9-aca)] (4), which was synthesised in high yield from [Ag2(9-aca)2] and 2-methylbenzimidazole (2-Mebenz-imH) in acetonitrile, suggests that this complex is isostructural with 2 and 3.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0130" view="all">In an attempt to recrystallise [Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) from ethanol the silver-free, monohydrate salt, (2-Mebenz-imH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(9-aca)·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), crystallised and was subsequently characterised using X-ray crystallography (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>). The cationic nature of the benzimidazolate was established from difference electron density maps which clearly showed the NH protons. The bond lengths and geometry are as expected for a benzimidazolate cation and carboxylate anion. The water molecules link 9-aca<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions into chains parallel to the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis and the benzimidazolate cations link the chains by hydrogen bonds to water and to one of the carboxylate oxygen atoms (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>, ). The 2-Mebenz-imH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations lie between the 9-aca<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions generating π-stacked columns, also running parallel to the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis () and linking the structure into sheets. The interplanar distances between the mean plane of the benzimidazolate cation and the neighbouring anthracene ring are 3.16 and 3.51<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (under symmetry operation <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In an attempt to recrystallise [Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)2(9-aca)] (4) from ethanol the silver-free, monohydrate salt, (2-Mebenz-imH2)(9-aca)⋅H2O (5), crystallised and was subsequently characterised using X-ray crystallography ( ). The cationic nature of the benzimidazolate was established from difference electron density maps which clearly showed the NH protons. The bond lengths and geometry are as expected for a benzimidazolate cation and carboxylate anion. The water molecules link 9-aca- anions into chains parallel to the a axis and the benzimidazolate cations link the chains by hydrogen bonds to water and to one of the carboxylate oxygen atoms ( , ). The 2-Mebenz-imH2 + cations lie between the 9-aca- anions generating π-stacked columns, also running parallel to the a axis () and linking the structure into sheets. The interplanar distances between the mean plane of the benzimidazolate cation and the neighbouring anthracene ring are 3.16 and 3.51Å (under symmetry operation x -1, y, z).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0135" view="all">[Ag(2-Mebenz-im)] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) was synthesised from [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and 2-methylbenzimidazole in methanol and the product formed in good yield (79%) (). The small changes in the reaction conditions, compared to the synthesis of [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-Mebenz-imH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) (methanol as opposed to acetonitrile and elevated temperature), has led to a product that is structurally quite different and an absence of the 9-aca<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion. Although the IR spectrum of <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> contained bands for the imidazolate ligand, distinctive bands for the carboxylate moiety were not observed. Microanalytical data indicate a Ag:2-Mebenz-im ratio of 1:1 and that the imidazole has been deprotonated at the amine nitrogen (N–H) atom to form the anion, 2-Mebenz-im<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: [Ag(2-Mebenz-im)] (6) was synthesised from [Ag2(9-aca)2] and 2-methylbenzimidazole in methanol and the product formed in good yield (79%) (). The small changes in the reaction conditions, compared to the synthesis of [Ag2(2-Mebenz-imH)4](9-aca)2 (4) (methanol as opposed to acetonitrile and elevated temperature), has led to a product that is structurally quite different and an absence of the 9-aca- anion. Although the IR spectrum of 6 contained bands for the imidazolate ligand, distinctive bands for the carboxylate moiety were not observed. Microanalytical data indicate a Ag:2-Mebenz-im ratio of 1:1 and that the imidazole has been deprotonated at the amine nitrogen (N-H) atom to form the anion, 2-Mebenz-im-.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0140" view="all">[Ag(Benz-im)] (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>), [Ag(2-Ph-im)] (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>) and [Ag(4,5-CN-im)] (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>) formulate in a similar manner to <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, and the <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectrum of the only sparingly soluble complex, (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), contained peaks for the 2-Ph-im<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion and no aca<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> peaks were observed. It is thought that these largely insoluble materials, (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>), form as polymeric chains in which the silver is coordinated to the deprotonated amine N of one imidazolate ligand and the imine nitrogen of a neighbouring imidazolate ligand (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>). Similar polymeric chains have been reported for the silver(I)–4-nitroimidazolate complex, [Ag(4-NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-im)] (4-NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-imH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-nitroimidazole) , and also for metal-imidazolate complexes of Ni(II), Cu(II), Zn(II) and Ag(I) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: [Ag(Benz-im)] (7), [Ag(2-Ph-im)] (8) and [Ag(4,5-CN-im)] (9) formulate in a similar manner to 6, and the 1H NMR spectrum of the only sparingly soluble complex, (8), contained peaks for the 2-Ph-im- anion and no aca- peaks were observed. It is thought that these largely insoluble materials, (6-9), form as polymeric chains in which the silver is coordinated to the deprotonated amine N of one imidazolate ligand and the imine nitrogen of a neighbouring imidazolate ligand ( ). Similar polymeric chains have been reported for the silver(I)-4-nitroimidazolate complex, [Ag(4-NO2-im)] (4-NO2-imH=4-nitroimidazole) , and also for metal-imidazolate complexes of Ni(II), Cu(II), Zn(II) and Ag(I) .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0145" view="all">In the syntheses of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold> it is interesting to note the influence of the p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> of the imidazole ligand and also the reaction solvent. As expected, imidazoles with relatively low p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> values (Benz-imH p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> 5.4; 2-Ph-imH p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> 5.23; 4,5-CN-imH p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> 5.2) had a greater tendency to deprotonate (yielding the imidazolate complexes <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>8</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, respectively). The presence of a coordinating metal ion will also lower the p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> of the imidazole . With 2-Me-imH, 4-Ph-imH and 2-Mebenz-imH (p<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">a</ce:inf> values of 7.75, 6.1 and 6.19, respectively) the imidazole ligand remains neutral and the respective imidazole/carboxylate complexes, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, form from [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] when the reactions are conducted in the polar, aprotic solvent, MeCN. In the reaction of [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] with 2-Mebenz-imH the solvent appears to also be an important factor as the protic solvent, MeOH, promotes formation of the imidazolate complex, [Ag(2-Mebenz-im)] (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) and, presumably, the free carboxylic acid, 9-acaH. The tenuous nature of [Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) is exemplified by the fact that dissolution in refluxing EtOH causes complex disintegration and formation of the imidazolium salt, (2-Mebenz-imH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(9-aca).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the syntheses of 1-9 it is interesting to note the influence of the pK a of the imidazole ligand and also the reaction solvent. As expected, imidazoles with relatively low pK a values (Benz-imH pK a 5.4; 2-Ph-imH pK a 5.23; 4,5-CN-imH pK a 5.2) had a greater tendency to deprotonate (yielding the imidazolate complexes 7, 8 and 9, respectively). The presence of a coordinating metal ion will also lower the pK a of the imidazole . With 2-Me-imH, 4-Ph-imH and 2-Mebenz-imH (pK a values of 7.75, 6.1 and 6.19, respectively) the imidazole ligand remains neutral and the respective imidazole/carboxylate complexes, 2, 3 and 4, form from [Ag2(9-aca)2] when the reactions are conducted in the polar, aprotic solvent, MeCN. In the reaction of [Ag2(9-aca)2] with 2-Mebenz-imH the solvent appears to also be an important factor as the protic solvent, MeOH, promotes formation of the imidazolate complex, [Ag(2-Mebenz-im)] (6) and, presumably, the free carboxylic acid, 9-acaH. The tenuous nature of [Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)2(9-aca)] (4) is exemplified by the fact that dissolution in refluxing EtOH causes complex disintegration and formation of the imidazolium salt, (2-Mebenz-imH2)(9-aca).

The metal-free ligands were also screened and all proved to be inactive at the relatively high concentration of 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μg<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Biological activity

The growth inhibitory effects of the new Ag(I) complexes, AgNO3 and silver sulphadiazine were investigated against Gram-negative E. coli., Gram-positive MRSA and the fungal pathogen, C. albicans ( ). For direct comparisons with AgNO3 and silver sulphadiazine the activities (as MIC50 or MIC100 values) are reported as μM concentrations of administered Ag(I) ion. The metal-free ligands were also screened and all proved to be inactive at the relatively high concentration of 100μgcm-3.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0155" view="all">In all cases, the complexes were substantially more active against the fungal cells than the two bacterial species, a pattern which matched that previously observed with the N1-substituted imidazole/9-aca<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> Ag(I) complexes . These results are somewhat at variance with those observed for the Ag(I) complexes containing 2-hydroxymethyl-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-alkylimidazole ligands where, dependant on the chain length of the alkyl substituent on the imidazole, the activity against <ce:italic>E. coli</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>S. aureus</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>B. spirizizenii</ce:italic> exceeded that for <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic>
. In terms of Ag(I) content, there was no significant difference in the antibacterial and antifungal activities of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> compared to those of the Ag(I) complexes containing N1-substituted imidazole and 9-aca<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands . The insoluble, imidazolate complexes, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, were a lot less aggressive towards bacteria than the other Ag(I) complexes. Complexes <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>8</ce:bold> were the least active against <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> whilst the other Ag(I) complexes were <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> twice as active as the prescription drug, Ketoconazole (MIC<ce:inf loc="post">100</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In all cases, the complexes were substantially more active against the fungal cells than the two bacterial species, a pattern which matched that previously observed with the N1-substituted imidazole/9-aca- Ag(I) complexes . These results are somewhat at variance with those observed for the Ag(I) complexes containing 2-hydroxymethyl-N-alkylimidazole ligands where, dependant on the chain length of the alkyl substituent on the imidazole, the activity against E. coli, S. aureus and B. spirizizenii exceeded that for C. albicans . In terms of Ag(I) content, there was no significant difference in the antibacterial and antifungal activities of 1-4 and 6 compared to those of the Ag(I) complexes containing N1-substituted imidazole and 9-aca- ligands . The insoluble, imidazolate complexes, 7-9, were a lot less aggressive towards bacteria than the other Ag(I) complexes. Complexes 6-8 were the least active against C. albicans whilst the other Ag(I) complexes were ca. twice as active as the prescription drug, Ketoconazole (MIC100 =4.70μM) .

Test solutions/suspensions (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μg<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>) were injected directly into the haemocoel through the last pro-leg of the insect and survival was monitored after 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Two types of <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic> antifungal screening protocols were examined: (i) prophylactic treatment and (ii) the treatment of infection (pre-infected larvae). Larvae were infected with a lethal dose of <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> fungal cells) in each protocol. For the prophylactic treatment, the test compound was administered 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h prior to infection with <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic> cells, while for the treatment of infection experiments the compound was administered 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h after infection with <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic>. elements.clean_text: The insect larvae, G. mellonella, was used to conduct in vivo toxicity profiling on the new Ag(I) complexes and results were compared to an untreated control (no added compound) and also to the reference standards, silver nitrate and ketoconazole. Test solutions/suspensions (100μgcm-3) were injected directly into the haemocoel through the last pro-leg of the insect and survival was monitored after 72h. Death was confirmed by the lack of movement in response to stimulus together with discolouration of the cuticle. Two types of in vivo antifungal screening protocols were examined: (i) prophylactic treatment and (ii) the treatment of infection (pre-infected larvae). Larvae were infected with a lethal dose of C. albicans (2×106 fungal cells) in each protocol. For the prophylactic treatment, the test compound was administered 1h prior to infection with C. albicans cells, while for the treatment of infection experiments the compound was administered 1h after infection with C. albicans. Results are given in  .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0165" view="all">For the prophylactic treatment, all of the test complexes, with the exception of [Ag(2-Me-im)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(9-aca)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), offered a substantially greater chance of survival, in comparison to the untreated control, against infection by a lethal dose of <ce:italic>C. albicans</ce:italic>. When analysed in terms of μg<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> of compound, AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and ketoconazole gave the best protection. [Ag(2-Ph-im)] (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>) proved to be the most efficient of the new Ag(I) complexes which is somewhat surprising since this complex registered one of the higher MIC<ce:inf loc="post">100</ce:inf> values (6.21<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μM; 1.56<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μg<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>) in the <ce:italic>in vitro</ce:italic> testing against the fungus. For the treatment of infection, AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and ketoconazole again offered the best prognosis. Sample <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and the more insoluble materials, <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, proved to be the most active of the new complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For the prophylactic treatment, all of the test complexes, with the exception of [Ag(2-Me-im)2(9-aca)] (2), offered a substantially greater chance of survival, in comparison to the untreated control, against infection by a lethal dose of C. albicans. When analysed in terms of μgcm-3 of compound, AgNO3 and ketoconazole gave the best protection. [Ag(2-Ph-im)] (8) proved to be the most efficient of the new Ag(I) complexes which is somewhat surprising since this complex registered one of the higher MIC100 values (6.21μM; 1.56μgcm-3) in the in vitro testing against the fungus. For the treatment of infection, AgNO3 and ketoconazole again offered the best prognosis. Sample 2 and the more insoluble materials, 6-9, proved to be the most active of the new complexes.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0170" view="all">Overall, the survival rates of larvae treated with AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> were very similar in the prophylactic and the treatment of infection experiments (80% and 75%, respectively). However, whereas complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> did not offer significant protection when administered prophlytically (30% survival) it proved to be extremely beneficial when used to treat larvae that had been pre-infected with <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>. <ce:italic>albicans</ce:italic> (70% survival). This suggests that there may be substantial degradation of the complex in the 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h timeframe between complex administration and inoculation with the lethal dose of fungal cells. This trend contrasted with that of complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (40% prophylactic, 10% treatment of infection).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Overall, the survival rates of larvae treated with AgNO3 were very similar in the prophylactic and the treatment of infection experiments (80% and 75%, respectively). However, whereas complex 2 did not offer significant protection when administered prophlytically (30% survival) it proved to be extremely beneficial when used to treat larvae that had been pre-infected with C. albicans (70% survival). This suggests that there may be substantial degradation of the complex in the 1h timeframe between complex administration and inoculation with the lethal dose of fungal cells. This trend contrasted with that of complex 4 (40% prophylactic, 10% treatment of infection).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0175" view="all">The trends found for the two sets of <ce:italic>in vivo</ce:italic> experiments using <ce:italic>G. mellonella</ce:italic> closely reflect those observed using Ag(I) 9-anthracene carboxylate complexes containing N1-substituted imidazoles , where again, AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> proved to be the most effective agent. This implies that the position of substituents on the imidazole ring does not impact greatly on the activity of the Ag(I) complex.</ce:para>

This implies that the position of substituents on the imidazole ring does not impact greatly on the activity of the Ag(I) complex.

elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

[Ag2(9-aca)2] reacts with DMSO and a selection of substituted imidazoles giving [Ag4(DMSO)4(9-aca)4] n  (1), [Ag(2-Me-imH)2(9-aca)] (2), [Ag(4-Ph-imH)2(9-aca)] (3), [Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)2(9-aca)] (4), [Ag(2-Mebenz-im)] (6), [Ag(Benz-im)] (7), [Ag(2-Ph-im)] (8) and [Ag(4,5-CN-im)] (9). In the carboxylate/imidazole complexes 2-4, the imidazole ligand remains neutral, whilst in 6-9 the imidazolate ligand deprotonates and no carboxylate ligand is present. Refluxing 4 in EtOH gives the metal-free, imidazolium salt, 2-Mebenz-imH2)(9-aca)⋅H2O (5). The Ag(I) complexes are very active against C. albicans, and moderately active against MRSA and E. coli. A number of the complexes offer a good prognosis for G. mellonella infected with a lethal dose of C. albicans cells.

Chemical synthesis

[Ag4(DMSO)4(9-aca)4] n  (1)

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (0.100g, 0.15mmoles) was dissolved in dimethylsulfoxide (4cm3) and the mixture heated to 80°C for 20min. Ethanol (15cm3) was added and the solution was brought to reflux and then filtered. The filtrate was left to stand and after 3days yellow, needle-like crystals were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol and allowed to air-dry (0.062g yield 50%). Soluble in MeCN and DMSO. Molecular weight 814.44gmol-1. Anal. Calc.: C, 50.14; H, 3.71. Found: C, 50.22; H, 3.70%. IR (cm-1): 3411, 3050, 1620, 1587, 1565, 1538, 1427, 1389, 1320, 1276, 1018. 1H NMR (δ, DMSO): 8.45 (s, 1H); 8.18 (m, 2H); 8.05 (m, 2H); 7.48 (m, 4H); 2.56 (s, 6H).

[Ag(2-Me-imH)2(9-aca)] (2)

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (0.068g, 0.10mmoles) was dissolved in acetonitrile (10cm3) and a solution of 2-methylimidazole (0.035g, 0.40mmoles) in acetonitrile (2cm3) was added dropwise with stirring. A white precipitate immediately formed which quickly redissolved. The solution was stirred for 1h at room temperature and a yellow precipitate formed. The yellow solid was collected by filtration, washed with a small portion of ethanol and diethyl ether. The yellow solid was recrystallised from acetonitrile to yield light-yellow crystals suitable for X-ray crystal analysis (0.050g yield 51%). Soluble in MeOH, EtOH, MeCN and DMSO. Molecular weight: 493.31gmol-1. Anal. Calc.: C, 56.00; H, 4.29; N, 11.36. Found: C, 55.70; H, 4.29; N, 11.08%. IR (cm-1): 3047, 2909, 2855, 2685, 1590, 1554, 1484, 1422, 1386, 1358, 1318, 1275, 1166, 1130, 1113, 1013. 1H NMR (δ, DMSO): 8.43 (s, 1H); 8.20 (m, 2H); 8.08 (m, 2H); 7.50 (m, 4H); 7.08 (s, 4H); 2.47 (s, 6H).

[Ag(4-Ph-imH)2(9-aca)] (3)

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (0.658g, 1.00mmoles) was dissolved in hot acetonitrile (100cm3) and the solution was filtered to remove any undissolved material. 4-Phenylimidazole (0.438g, 3.04mmoles) was dissolved in hot acetonitrile and added to the hot solution of [Ag2(9-aca)2] n . The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 0.5h. The suspension was filtered and the beige precipitate was washed with a small portion of cold ethanol and air-dried (0.887g yield 81%). Soluble in DMSO. Molecular weight: 473.32gmol-1. Calc.: C, 64.19; H, 4.08; N, 9.07%. Found: C, 63.74; H, 4.14; N, 8.88%. IR (cm-1): 3430, 3280, 3129, 3057, 2977, 2821, 2709, 2633, 1614, 1579, 1553, 1495, 1442, 1424, 1387, 1355, 1318, 1273, 1180, 1136, 1073, 1029, 1012. 1H NMR (δ, DMSO): 8.47 (s, 1H); 8.14 (m, 2H); 8.06 (m, 2H); 7.88 (s, 2H); 7.83 (s, 4H); 7.59 (s, 2H); 7.48 (m, 4H); 7.39 (t, 4H); 7.25 (t, 2H).

[Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)2(9-aca)] (4)

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (1.000g, 1.52mmoles) was dissolved in hot acetonitrile (100cm3) and the solution was filtered to remove any undissolved material. The filtrate was brought to reflux and a solution of 2-methylbenzimidazole (0.804g, 6.08mmoles) in hot acetonitrile (30cm3) was added. A white precipitate immediately formed. The suspension was removed from the heat source and was stirred at room temperature for 1h. The beige solid was filtered off, washed with a small portion of cold ethanol and air-dried (1.562g yield 87%). Soluble in hot MeOH and DMSO. Molecular weight: 461.32gmol-1. Anal. Calc.: C, 62.74; H, 4,25; N, 9.44. Found: C, 62.40; H, 4.17; N, 9.44%. IR (cm-1): 3446, 3047, 2524, 1888, 1625, 1599, 1558, 1532, 1456, 1427, 1388, 1318, 1282, 1223, 1041, 1005. 1H NMR (δ, DMSO): 8.63 (s, 1H); 8.09 (m, 2H); 8.03 (s, 2H); 7.56 (m, 4H); 7.49 (m, 4H); 7.15 (m, 4H). The signal for the protons of the methyl groups are masked by the large residual peak for non-deuterated DMSO (ca. 2.5ppm).

(2-Mebenz-imH2)(9-aca)⋅H2O (5)

In an attempt to recrystallise [Ag(2-Mebenz-imH)2(9-aca)] (4) from ethanol the silver-free, monohydrate salt, (5), crystallised and was subsequently characterised using X-ray crystallography.

[Ag(2-Mebenz-im)] (6)

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (0.500g, 0.76mmoles) was suspended in methanol (50cm3) at room temperature. 2-Methylbenzimidazole (0.201g, 1.52mmoles) was dissolved in methanol (10cm3) and added to the stirring suspension of [Ag2(9-aca)2]. The mixture was heated and a beige precipitate formed. The solid was filtered while hot, washed with methanol and allowed to air-dry (0.288g yield 79%). Insoluble in water and all common solvents. Molecular weight: 239.04gmol-1. Anal. Calc.: C, 40.19; H, 2.96; N, 11.72. Found: C, 40.27; H, 2.97; N, 11.24%. IR (cm-1): 3434, 3056, 3025, 2915, 1868, 1751, 1608, 1579, 1473, 1448, 1397, 1285, 1226, 1148, 1110, 1076, 1002.

[Ag(Benz-im)] (7)

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (0.200g, 0.30mmoles) was suspended in methanol (40cm3) at room temperature and a solution of benzimidazole (0.072g, 0.60mmoles) in methanol (5cm3) was added to the suspension. A beige precipitate formed and the suspension was stirred at room temperature for 0.5h. The beige solid was filtered, washed with cold methanol and air-dried (0.093g yield 68%). Insoluble in water and all common solvents. Molecular weight: 225.01gmol-1. Anal. Calc.: C, 37.36; H, 2.24; N, 12.45. Found: C, 37.65; H, 2.29; N, 11.97%. IR (cm-1): 3443, 3073, 1759, 1609, 1584, 1463, 1453, 1365, 1300, 1281, 1239, 1185, 1145, 1113, 1015, 999.

[Ag(2-Ph-im)] (8)

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (0.500g, 0.76mmoles) was dissolved in hot acetonitrile (40cm3) and the solution was filtered to remove any undissolved material. 2-Phenylimidazole (0.219g, 1.52mmoles) was dissolved in hot acetonitrile (20cm3) and this was added to the hot [Ag2(9-aca)2] solution. The resulting suspension was stirred at room temperature for 0.25h. The beige precipitate was filtered, washed with ethanol and air-dried (0.246g yield 64%). The complex was only slightly soluble in DMSO.

[Ag(4,5-CN-im)] (9)

[Ag2(9-aca)2] (0.500g, 0.76mmoles) was dissolved in hot acetonitrile (50cm3) and the solution filtered to remove any undissolved material. 4,5-Dicyanoimidazole (0.359g, 3.04mmoles) was dissolved in acetonitrile (5cm3) and added to the hot [Ag2(9-aca)2] solution. A beige precipitate immediately formed and the suspension was stirred at room temperature for 1h. The beige solid was filtered, washed with a small portion of cold ethanol and air-dried (0.240g yield 70%). Insoluble in water and all common solvents. Molecular weight: 224.97gmol-1. Anal. Calc.: C, 26.69; H, 0.49; N, 24.91. Found: C, 26.62; H, 0.41; N, 24.59%. IR (cm-1): 3534, 2227, 2176, 1748, 1720, 1583, 1492, 1471, 1457, 1438, 1321, 1303, 1283, 1250, 1115, 1105, 958, 878, 861.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Molecular weight: 251.05gmol-1. Anal. Calc.: C, 43.06; H, 2.82; N, 11.16. Found: C, 43.62; H, 2.81; N, 10.58%. IR (cm-1): 3445, 3040, 1601, 1578, 1482, 1458, 1413, 1318, 1298, 1280, 1147, 1074, 1023. 1H NMR (δ, DMSO): 7.92 (d, 2H); 7.41 (t, 2H); 7.33 (m, 1H); 7.24 (s, 1H); 7.02 (s, 1H).

For the prophylactic treatment, all of the test complexes, with the exception of [Ag(2-Me-im)2(9-aca)] (2), offered a substantially greater chance of survival, in comparison to the untreated control, against infection by a lethal dose of C. albicans. When analysed in terms of μgcm-3 of compound, AgNO3 and ketoconazole gave the best protection. [Ag(2-Ph-im)] (8) proved to be the most efficient of the new Ag(I) complexes which is somewhat surprising since this complex registered one of the higher MIC100 values (6.21μM; 1.56μgcm-3) in the in vitro testing against the fungus. For the treatment of infection, AgNO3 and ketoconazole again offered the best prognosis. Sample 2 and the more insoluble materials, 6-9, proved to be the most active of the new complexes.

Table 4. Survival (%) of G. mellonella larvae 72h after being infected with a lethal dose of C. albicans (2×10^6 fungal cells). For prophylactic treatment, the test compound was administered 1h prior to infection with C. albicans cells, while for the treatment of infection experiments the compound was administered 1h after infection with the fungal cells. Compounds were administered at a concentration of 100μgcm^-3). Data for the control, silver nitrate and ketoconazole have previously been published [6].

| Test compound | Dosage μgcm^-3 (μmolAg(I) cm^-3) | % Survival | % Survival |
|---------------|-------------------------------|------------|------------|
|               |                               | Prophylactic | Treatment of infection |
| Control       |                               | 10         | 10         |
| Ketoconazole  | 100 (0)                       | 75         | 75         |
| Silver nitrate| 100 (0.59)                    | 80         | 75         |
| 1             | 100 (0.49)                     | 50         | 30         |
| 2             | 100 (0.20)                     | 30         | 70         |
| 3             | 100 (0.21)                     | 45         | 20         |
| 4             | 100 (0.22)                     | 40         | 10         |
| 6             | 100 (0.42)                     | 40         | 50         |
| 7             | 100 (0.44)                     | 60         | 50         |
| 8             | 100 (0.39)                     | 70         | 60         |
| 9             | 100 (0.44)                     | 60         | 60         |
